results.title: A Scrap of paper and a piece of string
results.creator_credit: John Korty and Exploring for the National Broadcasting Company
results.brief_description: An animated film about a scrap of paper which boasts of being more useful than a piece of string. However, after turning into a paper boat and getting blown over in the water, the paper finds the string of use after all. Suitable for lower and middle primary levels.

results.title: Noddy goes to school
results.creator_credit: Brian Cosgrove, Mark Hall, CPL and Stop Frame Productions
results.brief_description: Based on the Noddy stories by Enid Blyton. A series of incidents cause Noddy to come to the realisation that he should go to school to learn to read. Narrated by Richard Briers.

results.title: Thomas Hardy: a man who noticed things
results.brief_description: A dramatised documentary about the life and loves of Thomas Hardy. Narrated by Charles Causley, the film looks at Hardy’s love for his home and family, his suffering for animals, his delight in both secular and sacred music, and his notorious love affairs. Illustrates how Hardy’s work related directly to such aspects of his life. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: Invitation to archery
results.creator_credit: American Archery Council and Athletic Institute
results.brief_description: Explores the history of archery and examines modern equipment available. Includes segments on target shooting, field archery, bot hunting and fishing. Suitable for upper primary and secondary levels.

results.title: Shortspell
results.creator_credit: Stuart Wynn Jones and Kinetic Film Enterprises
results.brief_description: An animated review of the alphabet in which each letter becomes a picture and each picture becomes the next letter. Both sound and picture are drawn directly onto the film by the artist.

results.title: You'll soon get the hang of it
results.brief_description: Aims to impart the basic psychology of training and motivation and how to apply it when passing on knowledge and skills to a trainee. John Cleese uses a variety of situations - manual, clerical and technical - to put over the essential points and illustrate the major pitfalls.

results.title: Zero de conduite = Zero in conduct
results.brief_description: Banned until 1945, this film has strong ties to surrealist films of the 1920’s. Vigo depicts the opressive life in a French provincial boarding school and the eventual rebellion by the boys against the authority figures, symbolised in the famous pillow fight, the raising of the flag on the roof, the slow motion procession and the styalised crucifiction of the supervisor. Cinematography by Boris Kaufman, music by Maurice Jaubert.

results.title: When will they realise we're living in the 20th century?
results.brief_description: John Cleese plays the roles of both the Shop Steward and the Production Director, each of whom tells his side of the story to the audience regarding a production dispute. As the film proceeds, the mistaken assumptions, actions and attitudes that precipitated the dispute are revealed. Suitable for upper secondary and tertiary levels.

results.title: Child's play
results.brief_description: Shows how mental, social, emotional and physical growth are linked to a child’s form of play and how these forms change as the child grows older. Illustrates how play allows children to work out their feelings and frustrations as well as providing a stage for creative ideas and fantasies.

results.title: Sealsong (D)
results.creator_credit: Stephen Best, International Fund for Animal Welfare and Mobius Productions
results.brief_description: Shows the annual migration of the harp seals to the coast of Newfoundland, where they await the birth of their white pups which are subsequnetly brutally slaughtered for their fur by seal hunters. Each year Brian Davies of the International Fund for Animal Welfare comes to the sea nureries in his fight to save the seals. In this film he makes a strong plea for their preservation. Narrated by Jack Lord and Brian Davies. Restricted: postprimary schools only. WARNING - MAY CONTAIN DISTURBING IMAGES.
